reviewText:
Even though WRC 5 makes improvements on WRC 4, it's still a very sketchy title.

The following is my judgement whilst keeping in mind that it's supposed to be a sim-cade game, and not a DiRT Rally challenger as far as gameplay goes.

The physics are a bit wonky, engine behaviour is strange, general car behaviour is largely inconsistent on a lot of stages (in the context of rally), and the pacenots get so behind at times it's impossible to drive a stage fast without knowing the stage layout by memory; it's a problem when pacenotes aren't recorded specially for a stage.

The stages themselves feel a bit lifeless, and some of them are quite wide-open and boring. The video settings for a PC title are lacking, and the performance of the game itself is disappointing due to poor optimisation for the platform. The sounds have improved on what was in WRC 4, but they're still pretty bad, especially for the co-driver and some of the general car sounds.

I'm sure this game will improve when people release physics mods, etc. for the game, but until then, I'd just like a good product out of the box, and for the game to run well on PC.

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying I'm not an absolute hardcore sim-racer - I don't have a wheel or a racing rig, I just play driving games using an XBOX One controller. PCARS, DiRT Rally, Race 07, etc, etc - I own and play them all.

WRC 5 is rough around the edges, but with some TLC I think the game could go from good to great. It's not DiRT Rally, but it's also not awful. It's not another Milestone travesty, so we don't have to worry about garbage like the sound dropping out after two stages.

I'll start with the bad:

- Robotic co-driver: You do get the option of a woman co-driver, but both male and female options are spliced from sound clips rather than smooth pace notes like DiRT Rally or Dirt 2 / 3. It's not bad (and the pace notes are effective), but it's something to note.
- Poor engine sounds: The cars sound like toys.
- No actual routes: The courses are approximations of the real locations. It's close, but it's not the actual course.
- Wheel support: There's a limited set of supported wheels.

And now for the pros:

+ Classes: Junior WRC, WRC 2 and WRC. You get a good selection of classes and cars, plus all the licensed drivers and gear.
+ Career mode: The team stats are slightly randomized so you get a good selection of goals to choose from.
+ Stages: 5 unique stages and a repeat per rally, usually in a 2-2-2 format. The stages aren't terribly long, but they are fun to drive. Finland's scary at night.
+ Challenge mode: The MP challenge mode is pretty fun. Time trials on a specific stage using a specific team.

Reasonably, hard-core sim racers aren't going to like this. It's a balance of arcade racing and sim racing, using a real-world license. If you want a nice introduction to rally racing, this is a good place to start. It's better than WRC 4 (which isn't saying much, admittedly, but it's a marked improvement and is a decent little racing game).

7/10 - needs some work, but is playable and fun.

EDIT 2015-10-14: Patch 1.03 helped with the variable framerate and set DX11 as the primary launch mode, rather than DX9. I adjusted the cons to remove the framerate issues and upped my score to 7/10. The game still needs work, but it's not bad.

First impressions:

Graphics:  With a 4670k O/C'd to 4.3 ghz and a GTX 970 I'm getting very low frame rates (less than 60), even with all graphic settings set to LOW or OFF.  This is just at 1080p.  Very few options to change as well.

Wheel Support and Force Feedback:  Just atrocious....  No clutch pedal support whatsoever (don't think H shifter either, but haven't tried yet). Physics:  About what you would expect.   More arcade like but you do need to use the brakes in this game at least....

Rally school:  A complete joke.  Not even worth discussing.  You have to do the same courses for Basics, 2wd, and 4wd.  Honestly just a huge waste of time.

Overall:  With only an hour of playtime so far, I'm giving this game a 2/10.  This may change with further playtime, but currently its a buggy, laggy mess.  Stay far away from it.

I like it.

The stage design is good, the handling is decent, the graphics are average and the audio is mediocre.

The handling is quite forgiving and easy to get the hang of, but there's room to better yourself through practice.

There are 65 different stages ranging from 2 to 12 km spread across 13 locations.

The stage design itself is quite good, but the road surfaces themselves could use more bumps and camber changes.

The visuals aren't too impressive, but there are a lot of nice visual details around and being able to choose time of day and weather for any track is great. The car models and damage look pretty good too.

The audio isn't too impressive either and while the co-driver is functional, they sound pretty robotic.

They have handled the service-park repairs well, with partial repairs being an option and some components being completely replaced.

Overall I thoroughly enjoy the game and would recommend it if you're a fan of the WRC and Rally games.

I think WRC 5 is a commendable effort by Kylotonn and I look forward to the sequel should they make one, this game is a solid foundation for the next.

reviewText:
I really wish they didn't advertise the game as a simulator, because it definitely is not. What it is, however, is a casual game meant for rally and WRC fans.

If you're looking for realism, you won't find it here. The tracks are mostly fictional and the car physics are simcade level at best. The visuals are serviceable but dated and are reminiscent of racing games on last gen consoles.

The performance could be better, but the game should run fine on a modern low end system with some tinkering in the graphics options. With VSync off, I average around 70 fps on max settings with an r7 370 at 900p (45 fps at 1080p). Turning the shadows down a notch yielded a 10-15 fps boost.

There is plenty of content to play through in the solo campaign. You start out as a junior and have to work your way up every season to become a champion.  The rally school is a really nice addition for people who aren't familiar with rally techniques. There are random leaderboard challenges that appear from time to time that serve as a bit of side content. If you just want to drive and not worry about the career, there is a quick stage mode that has every track and car unlocked.

Overall, I would say the single player portion is very plain. You don't really need to do anything but drive. The car repairs, car setup, and team management have mostly been automated. While there are plenty of tracks, they are an example of quantity over quality. Most are short (<5 minutes) and have rather bland environments.

Also, don't get this for multiplayer unless you have friends to play it with since it's mostly dead.

tl;dr

If you just want to sit back with a controller (or whatever your preference) and have some casual rallying fun, then you should get this on a sale.

reviewText:
Introduction:

I've been playing Rally games since I got a DOS version of Lombard RAC Rally in the late 80's and Championship Rally for the Nintendo back in the early 90's (my sons), and later  Rally Championship 2000,  RalliSport Challenge, all of the Colin McRae rally games through to Dirt 2  as well as the  later Dirt games, and  although not classed as rally games the early  road  racing Need for Speed games, Richard Burns Rally , Sega Rally,  Xpand Rally   plus a few others I've forgotten the names of.   I've   loved most of  them for various reasons and  WRC 5 is no exception.

The latest iteration of World Rally Championship  v5 is IMO perhaps the best  in the WRC  franchise so far, with decent physics when driving on the various surfaces   such as gravel, snow dirt sand etc.  the sounds, including external  environmental sounds,  hitting various obstacles, the various  'tame' expletives your co driver  shouts  when you  crash or   have a near miss, are not the best, but all go to making  a decent  rally game experience.   For newcomers to rally games there's  a  useful  Rally School  mode and an easy driving styles  mode when playing  solo.





Modes of Play:


Solo Mode:

There are two main  modes of play, Solo and Multiplayer. Solo is divided into four more modes, 'Quick Stage', where you play just one stage of a rally, or   'Quick Rally' where you can choose to play any one of the rally  meets, including all of the stages. The third  solo mode  is   Career mode, where you play all of the championships  rally meets in a particular order; you can't  select   any rally, you have to play them in order according to the real World Championships, starting with the Monte Carlo Rally, then, you move to the next, i.e. Vodaphone Rally de Portugal etc etc.  Some stages in each rally are repeated but  with different road or environmental  conditions, such as day  and night, clear or icy etc.

If you wish to start a new career,  you can do so, but it will wipe all progress  from the career you've already started.

The final solo mode is the  Rally School, a useful tool if you are a novice, or not very confident rallying.    This is divided into five different   sections that initially cover the basics  such as pace notes, detailed angles, different kinds of turns and surfaces, accelerating and stopping on tarmac (the easiest surface to negociate), using the hand brakes etc.  Then there's coping with 2 wheel drive  4 wheel drive (two separate sections for this) and advanced techniques.  at the end of each section you have to put all you've learnt in that section together.  You are not able to skip any part of the  Rally School tutorials and you need to pass a certain standard in each  part to progress to the next.


Multiplayer Mode and Leaderboards:

The multiplayer options include online and offline multiplayer, quick match, online invitation and creating a private or public game.  These modes basically speak for themselves so there's  no need to go into detail.  The offline multiplayer  is  almost like playing single player, in that you race  singly between up to 8 players, each one  playing in turn, whereas with  the online multiplayer option, all players  race together, but  do not interact with each other (i.e, you can see them as Ghosts.  As I'm not primarily a multiplayer enthusiast, I can't expand on this area at this time.  I only like playing  vehicle based games online  with good friends as I'm embarrasingly  dire when it comes to technique and racing in general;  for example, looking at the world rankings for this game  20 hours into  the game being released  I stood at 377th out of 450  players, with a 45 second gap between my times and the leader and that was  just for one complete rally and championship type.  There are   three or four of these included in the game  (JWRC, WRC etc).  I felt like I was going as fast as the road conditions and my vehicle allowed,  yet being beaten by 45 seconds makes me wonder what I'm doing wrong.  Hopefully as I work through the rally school I'll improve somewhat. (fingers crossed). For those who are competitive, there are leader boards that show  overall  rankings for all players,  as well as  friends leader boards.


Control Options:

There are three configurable modes of control; Keyboard, Steering Wheel and Controller.  For any rally game enthusiast, the   Steering Wheel is the  best choice as you have more  'configurable' control over the keyboard,   and is the  most immersive control option;  for example you can  configure acceleration, brake and steering sensitivity with dead zones, whereas the  keyboard has no dead zones. The  Steering Wheel option also includes force feedback, (as does the Controller option) which gives a much greater feel and immersivness to the game, plus  your vehicle is much easier to control  compared to if you used a keyboard.  Unfortunately I've  still not unpacked my Logitech steering wheel, pedals and shifter since we moved house  (must do that soon). I've read that others have been having problems  with their  wheels not being supported.  Hopefully  this will be  addressed  in an update soon.  I found using the X-Box controller was  easier than the keyboard and included basic force feedback. There appears to be six degrees of freedom with this game, at least in some of the camera modes, for example, you can look from side to side, upwards and behind in  chase mode and in  cockpit mode  left and right and upwards.  Unfortunately the track IR hasn't been configured for any of the WTC games, so it's unlikely that we will be seeing  WRC5  Track IR enhanced, Maybe   Naturalpoint (the developers of the track IR system) may be considering  the latest title. The first 3 Dirt titles and some of the earlier Colin McRae as well as most of the other titles I mention at the beginning of this review   all have Track IR enhancements.  If this game gets it, it will add even more immersivness.

The game also works with the Novint Falcon a force feedback device that gives excellent force feedback, but as the   device was primarily designed for mouse based games and  games with guns, it's not  as easy to control your driving unless you use it in conjuction with the keyboard.



Driving Styles:

There are four driving styles to choose from  starting with easy, through to medium, hard and  expert.  I've only played it on easy so far so can't  expand on the differences yet.  I will be updating this  review as and when I continue to play the game as I'm only on the second rally  at the moment.




Repairing your vehicle:


You can configure/tune you car  (in the motor home) for various conditions  to ensure optimal driving.  Skill alone  won't  see you winning every race because if you  haven't set up your car for the right conditions for the stage you are about to enter, you'll find your  vehicle will  damage more readily.  You can only  repair your vehicle between  the main stages in any  rally and   depending on how much damage you have   you are likely  not going to be able to repair everything  because you are only allowed   an amount of time that represents the  time allowed  in the real WRC  championship;  i.e. 45 minutes,  so you need to prioritise  which areas you  repair, for example geras, engine, body work,  brakes, electronics, steering etc.  for those less experienced with   the  more recent rally games (the  last WRC   game and I think the  later dirt games have a similar  repair  process) you can  set repairs to automatic. If you select this the A.I. will repair what it considers the  most urgent  repairs. However, don't  ignore the manual process entirely because   damage can also be dependant on the players  style.

reviewText:
TL;DR consider getting this game if you want an arcady and more easy rally game.

Full story:
Many reviews seem to be comparing this game to Dirt Rally (I own both of these games), and the way this game is marketed suggests it is a rally simulator. However, people, who search for rally simulator will not find it here, because this game has quite arcady driving and damage models. That certainly will not appeal to Dirt Rally crowd, but I think people who are not into hardcore racing simulators would enjoy this game: this game has rally school, much less steep learning curve and it can be enjoyed without having a racing wheel. The tradeoff is not that realistic driving.

Is it better than WRC 4? Yes. It runs smoothly at 60 FPS (older game was locked to 30), the graphics seem to be a big improvement over WRC 4. The amount of cars is decent, but less than Dirt Rally offers and classes are limited to WRC, WRC-2 and J-WRC. The price compared to amount of content on offer (comparing to Dirt Rally) is quite high, but if you can get it on sale, it is worth the money.

Cons: it suffers from problem WRC 4 had as well: many special stages are on same pieces of road, so amount of unique roads is much smaller than number of stages. The rewind feature seems to be missing from WRC 4, now you just can restart from last checkpoint. Some signs of poor port from consoles to PC: key prompts seems to be bugged out, a lot of times Xbox controller prompts are shonwn for me when I only own a Logitech Driving Force GT, which has PS3 buttons on it.

As a conclusion I can say if you are into hardcore racing simulators, you own a decent raging wheel, then get Dirt Rally, it is much better game for you. If you are into more arcady and more casual fun, this might be worth it for you.

reviewText:
7.5/10 - Worth a visit, at the right price, for any rally fan.

First Impressions
+ 9 patches on pc, Kylotonn appears to be very committed and is listening to the community.
+ nice simple to navigate menus (though some may not be happy with no mouse control).
+ (since latest patches) able to detect all 3 components of my wheel setup.  including my Fanatec CSR Elite pedals and Thrustmater TH8A as separate USB conenctions.
- wish it would detect the Thrustmater TH8A in analog mode for handbrake (instead of needing to use sequential mode).
- overall sound needs improvement, engine sounds especially.  co-driver could also use work, has awkward pauses and sounds robotic.

Graphics and Visual Impression
+ runs just fine on triple screens (but no advanced rendering options).  appears to be well optimized (almost always 60 fps on triples with a single gtx 970).
- overall the visuals can't match visuals of DiRT Rally or other AAA racing games.
- no FOV or ability for full camera adjustments (but cockpit does give 5 view distance options).
- tracks could use more activity from crowd or wildlife.  feels lifeless.

Handling and Physics
+ decent damage modeling that effects handling (but have yet to see a full retirment).  few smart ideas with damage; stuck in a gear, loss of co-driver audio (electronics issues), etc.  fairly realistic repair format at service stops (can't fix tyres by 3%).
= sim-cade physics.  heavy cars and plenty of lateral grip when coasting makes it very easy to drive, but trail braking in to corners, and too heavy of accelreation in or out of corners can still be punished.  reminds me a lot of Colin McRae 2005 and similar... it's a very enjoyable drive, while not totally realistic.
= average at best force feedback.  advanced wheel options are lacking, but I've been able to get it to feel good at 900 degrees of rotation.

Track Selection
+ no deja vu, all 65 stages are unique.  353.7 KM of stages, 5 for each of the 13 coutries (one is repeated in a rally).  This is double that found in DiRT Rally, and still more a bit more than the 300 km quoted by Seb Loeb Rally Evo.
+ enjoyable stage designs, that feel authentic to the region.  reasonable track widths (not extremely wide and unrealistic).  good variation in terrain and turn types and corner combinations.
- stages are not real world recreations, as featured in DiRT Rally and Seb Loeb Rally Evo.
- some stages are very (2-3 km) short.  overall average is 5.4 km per stage (longest is 11 km).

Overall Experience

I'm really enjoying my time with WRC 5.  Those who only care about simulations can skip this title.  But if you're someone who is willing to play something a little more casual, you should be able to easily enjoy this experience.  Thing that makes rally awesome is learning new roads/routes... and this game will let you do that at a great volume.  Career mode is interesting enough as you make your climb from Junior, WRC 2, and finally to WRC.

Same good old WRC...
I played every WRC game since the series started. As a long-time follower of the series, the same formula that follows each new WRC installment can be again applied to WRC 5. Now, before i get into details, if you are a casual guy that doesn't know anything about rallying, don't play this, or don't expect to be any good. If you're a Richard Burns/rally sim crybaby, go away. This is not a simulation, it's not meant to be, but nor is it a casual game. If you're a NFS driver, you will suck at this.

The game doesn't offer more than it did before - WRC/WRC-2/J-WRC authentic cars, and relatively well done rallies of this year. They drastically changed some rallies compared to last year's, for better or worse (it comes to personal preferences and taste really). Each rally has 6 stages minimum (3 rallies have 7 of them). Gameplay is slightly more realistic/improved compared to the previous installment, but not very significantly, nor does it need to be in my opinion. What i think that WRC series desperately need is paying a bit more attention to details and possibly putting some more content there. I don't know whether developers of the WRC series are undermanned or lazy, but the game, like others before it, is unpolished in some minor details that can irritate certain fans of rally games. I, for instance, am fan of fast, gravel/dust/snow/ice rallies with tight roads. In short, i am a fan of fast and challenging rallies. And there are challenging rallies in WRC 5, i just don't enjoy most of those like i did with first versions of Rally Mexico, Jordan and Finland (although there's nothing wrong with WRC 5's Mexico and Finland rallies).

What annoys me the most about this game? Two things, very minor maybe, but important to me. First: i love dodging rocks and bottlenecks. There are very few bottlenecks in this game, and the little rocks that lie scattered on the edges of roads of Sardegna, Catalunya, Argentina, and Mexico, do not have hitboxes" at all.
